{{/message}} {{/verifyErrors}} Cambridge Dictionary +Plus My profile +Plus help Log out {{userName}} Cambridge Dictionary +Plus My profile +Plus help Log out Log in Sign up English UK Search Search Dictionary Translate Grammar Cambridge Dictionary +Plus English {{word}} {{beta}}Beta{{/beta}} {{preferredDictionaries}} {{^selected}} {{name}} {{/selected}} {{/preferredDictionaries}} Meaning of underground in English underground adjective, adverb uk Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio /ˌʌn.dəˈɡraʊnd/ us Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio /ˌʌn.dɚˈɡraʊnd/ underground adjective, adverb BELOW EARTH B2 below the surface of the earth; below ground: an underground cave/passage/cable Moles live underground.
More examples He suffers from claustrophobia so he never travels on underground trains.
Ten miners were trapped underground when the roof of the tunnel fell in.
Electrical power is supplied by underground cables.
Planes bombed the guerrilla positions yesterday in an attempt to flush out snipers from underground tunnels.
His grandfather had bought the land as an investment, guessing that there might be gold underground.

Learn the words you need to communicate with confidence.
underground adjective, adverb SECRET An underground activity is secret and usually illegal: an underground newspaper/movement The Communist Party was forced to go underground, and its leaders went into hiding.
Travelpix Ltd/Stone/GettyImages Thesaurus: synonyms and related words Railways railway lines Amtrak artery buffer cable railway electrify funicular grade crossing junction light railway metro monorail railroad railroad tie rapid-transit RR siding signal switch switchback track See more results underground noun PEOPLE people in society who are trying new and often shocking or illegal ways of living or forms of art: In Britain and the USA in the 1970s, the underground was powerful subversive force.
the underground group of people who secretly fight against the government: He was member of the underground, harassing the invading army.
Definition of underground from the Cambridge Academic Content Dictionary Cambridge University Press Examples of underground underground To do otherwise was to risk driving underground legitimate political expression, which would create worse problems in the long run.
From Cambridge English Corpus The problem that most participants of underground work face is that they are seldom seen and are therefore rarely recognized for their work.
From Cambridge English Corpus These examples are from the Cambridge English Corpus and from sources on the web.
Any opinions in the examples do not represent the opinion of the Cambridge Dictionary editors or of Cambridge University Press or its licensors.
More examples Fewer examples The fracture was caused during the construction of storm sewer, involving underground work beneath the defendants' mains, by third party.
From Cambridge English Corpus All underground members were put on trial and convicted.
From Cambridge English Corpus have no problem with anyone on the underground who hates the music for what it is.
From Cambridge English Corpus While one of the timed walks went into an underground station and through subway, the second remained outdoors, to create an acoustic disjunction.
From Cambridge English Corpus The plans include development of new performing space underground and new entrance.
From Cambridge English Corpus Although juvenile slatey-grey snakes often are arboreal during their nocturnal activity, most diurnal retreat-sites of our radio-tracked adults were terrestrial, and generally underground.
From Cambridge English Corpus Next the search algorithm for the underground source locating robot is addressed.
From Cambridge English Corpus The use of novel sensing technologies such as ground penetrating radar and inertial sensors to guide underground coal mining machines is described in detail.
From Cambridge English Corpus There was brief resistance to prohibiting women from working underground.
From Cambridge English Corpus We want to find practical solutions to the underground's problems, and to modernise its key assets such as track, signalling, bridges and embankments.

From the Hansard archive Example from the Hansard archive.
Contains Parliamentary information licensed under the Open Parliament Licence v3.0 The smaller lines could sometimes be undergrounded with advantage.

Contains Parliamentary information licensed under the Open Parliament Licence v3.0 Before reaching decision, he invited representations on how requirement of undergrounding would affect the viability of the project.
